downscale package

Submodules

downscale.Downscaler module

class downscale.Downscaler.Downscaler(modelfile=None)

Bases: object

creates the object and reads the sklearn estimator from file if passed

read_model(modelfile)

reads the sklearn estimator from file

Parameters

modelfile (string) – name of the .joblib file to read

save(data, path)

recives a xarray dataset saves it of disk

Parameters

  • data (xarray.dataset) – dataset to save on disk

  • path (string) – the path where to save the netCDF file

save_by_month(data, path)

splits a dataset based on year and month, assigns to them a name and saves them of disk

Parameters

  • data (xarray.dataset) – dataset to save on disk

  • path (string) – the path where to save the netCDF file

scale(data, target_name)

use the estimator saved in the model attribute to apply a machine learning algorithm and make a prediction on a dataset

Parameters

  • data (xarray.dataset) – dataset (with 3 dimenstions:longitude,latitude,time, with data relative to only 1 longitude and 1 latitude) containing the data to downscale

  • target_name (string) – the name of the datavariable where to put the scaled data

Returns

new dataset with an extra datavariable containing the old data and the scaled data

Return type

xarray.dataset

downscale.Model module

class downscale.Model.Model(name)

Bases: object

class that creates a scikit-learn estimator and provides methods to recive divide and use a xarray dataset to train evaluate and save the estimator

accuracy(X_test, y_test)

makes prediction and confront them to the recived numpyarray to calculate the score,explained variance, max error,mean absolute error, mean squared error, median absolute error and r2 score and saves them as a string in the class attribute Model.stats

Parameters

  • X_test (pandas.dataframe) – Pandas dataframe used to make predictions

  • y_test (numpy.array) – numpy array used to evaluate the accuracy of the predictions

modify_model(C=None, cache_size=None, coef0=None, degree=None, epsilon=None, gamma=None, kernel=None, max_iter=None, shrinking=None, tol=None, bootstrap=None, ccp_alpha=None, criterion=None, max_depth=None, max_features=None, max_leaf_nodes=None, max_samples=None, min_impurity_decrease=None, min_impurity_split=None, min_samples_leaf=None, min_samples_split=None, min_weight_fraction_leaf=None, n_estimators=None, n_jobs=None, oob_score=None, random_state=None, verbose=None, warm_start=None)

set some features to the estimator

Parameters

  • C (float, optional) – Regularization parameter. The strength of the regularization is inversely proportional to C. Must be strictly positive.. Defaults to 1.

  • cache_size (float, optional) – Specify the size of the kernel cache (in MB).. Defaults to 200.

  • coef0 (float, optional) – Independent term in kernel function. Defaults to 1.0.

  • degree (int, optional) – Degree of the polynomial kernel function (‘poly’). Defaults to 3.

  • epsilon (float, optional) – Epsilon in the epsilon-SVR model. Defaults to 0.1.

  • gamma ({'scale', 'auto'} or float, optional) – Kernel coefficient for ‘rbf’, ‘poly’ and ‘sigmoid’. Defaults to ‘scale’.

  • kernel (string, optional) – Specifies the kernel type to be used in the algorithm. Defaults to rbf.

  • max_iter (int, optional) – Hard limit on iterations within solver, or -1 for no limit. Defaults to -1.

  • shrinking (bool, optional) – Whether to use the shrinking heuristic.. Defaults to True.

  • tol (float, optional) – Tolerance for stopping criterion. Defaults to 1e-3.

  • bootstrap (bool, optional) – Whether bootstrap samples are used when building trees. If False, the whole dataset is used to build each tree. Defaults to True.

  • ccp_alpha (non-negative float, optional) – Complexity parameter used for Minimal Cost-Complexity Pruning. Defaults to 0.0.

  • criterion (string, optional) – {“squared_error”, “absolute_error”, “poisson”},The function to measure the quality of a split. Defaults to “squared_error”.

  • max_depth (int, optional) – The maximum depth of the tree. If None, then nodes are expanded until all leaves are pure or until all leaves contain less than min_samples_split samples. Defaults to None.

  • max_features (int or float, optional) – The number of features to consider when looking for the best split:. Defaults to 1.0.

  • max_leaf_nodes (int, optional) – Grow trees with max_leaf_nodes in best-first fashion. Best nodes are defined as relative reduction in impurity. If None then unlimited number of leaf nodes.. Defaults to None.

  • max_samples (int or float, optional) – If bootstrap is True, the number of samples to draw from X to train each base estimator. Defaults to None.

  • min_impurity_decrease (_type_, optional) – _description_. Defaults to None.

  • min_impurity_split (float, optional) – A node will be split if this split induces a decrease of the impurity greater than or equal to this value.. Defaults to 0.

  • min_samples_leaf (int or float, optional) – The minimum number of samples required to be at a leaf node. Defaults to 1.

  • min_samples_split (int or float, optional) – The minimum number of samples required to split an internal node. Defaults to 2.

  • min_weight_fraction_leaf (float, optional) – The minimum weighted fraction of the sum total of weights (of all the input samples) required to be at a leaf node. Samples have equal weight when sample_weight is not provided.. Defaults to 0.0.

  • n_estimators (int, optional) – The number of trees in the forest. Defaults to 100.

  • n_jobs (int, optional) – The number of jobs to run in parallel. Defaults to None.

  • oob_score (bool, optional) – Whether to use out-of-bag samples to estimate the generalization score. Defaults to False.

  • random_state (int, optional) – Controls both the randomness of the bootstrapping of the samples used when building trees (if bootstrap=True) and the sampling of the features to consider when looking for the best split at each node. Defaults to None.

  • verbose (int, optional) – Controls the verbosity when fitting and predicting. Defaults to 0.

  • warm_start (bool, optional) – When set to True, reuse the solution of the previous call to fit and add more estimators to the ensemble, otherwise, just fit a whole new forest.. Defaults to False.

save(path)

saves the estimator in a file Model.name.joblib and the relative accuracy stats in a file Model.name.txt

Parameters

path (string) – he path where to save the file on disk

train(X_train, y_train)

trains the estimator

Parameters

  • X_train (pandas.dataframe) – data to use as features

  • y_train (numpy.array) – data to use as target

train_test_split(data, features, target, train_start, train_end, test_start, test_end)

splits the dataset in train and test based on date, and splits both the train and test in features and target

Parameters

  • data (xarray.dataset) – dataset with dimensions longitude,latitude and time, with data relative to only 1 longitude and 1 latitude

  • features (string) – the names of the datavariables used as features

  • target (string) – the name of the datavariable used as target

  • train_start (datetime64[ns]) – first date of the training set

  • train_end (datetime64[ns]) – last date of the training set

  • test_start (datetime64[ns]) – first date of the test set

  • test_end (datetime64[ns]) – last date of the test set

Returns

pandas dataframe with the features and a numpy array with the target respecctively for the training and test sets

Return type

(pandas.dataframe,numpy.array,pandas.dataframe,numpy.array)
